data.title: [Troubleshooting] Animation's layers looking off in Safari
data.description: The order of my layers looks correct on other browsers, but they are mixed in Safari. Why?
data.body:
The issue here is related to the Translation Z  property.

This property gets complicated and inconsistent across browsers, unfortunately. Translation z , element order , and z-index  combine and get messy.

Try checking and playing with the values set on the Translation Z  and Z index  properties on your animation. This should resolve the issue.

data.title: [Troubleshooting] Animation with stroke-dashoffset looking off in Safari
data.description: My animation looks great on other browsers, but it breaks in Safari. What's going on?
data.body: The problem is that Safari does not support negative stroke-dashoffset. You'd need to shift all your values to positive numbers for this feature to work properly in Safari.

data.title: GIF and Video export times
data.description: When I try to export my animation, the video and gif options never finish (and eventually grey out). What's going on?
data.body: If you're dealing with a huge animation with a lot of heavy assets, please keep in mind that the app doesn’t give good feedback when it does long-running exports; I recommend giving the export up to 30-45mins (depending on the complexity & resolution of the project; could take longer!)

data.title: Performant animations for iOS
data.description: My animations seem to crawl on iOS, what can I do?
data.body:
Especially if you're using any of Animator's interactivity features, it's worth thinking about what you're building as "software" rather than a design.  I.e. even though the interface feels like a design tool, what you're creating is a production UI.

As part of that mindset, there's really no silver bullet for what limits to respect, etc. — just as you can write non-performant code in Swift, you can create a non-performant UI animation in Animator.  The best way to figure it out is to iterate, get it on a device, and iterate again.

Re: iOS specifically, have you tried out the Lottie export functionality?  You'll find that it's generally more performant on iOS & Android because it uses native-based renderers instead of web renderers.  Just note that Lottie doesn't support any interactions, and there are a handful of other features that won't translate 100%.  It all comes back to iteration & experimentation.

Finally, if what you're delivering is a prototype or explanation aid instead of slated-for-production UI, you may find some success in exporting an mp4, which should render performantly on just about any device.

data.title: [Troubleshooting] Animator permissions
data.description: Due to my company's security restrictions I need to set permissions to be able to start my Animator trial.
data.body:
You should be good to go if you whitelist the following domains:

inkstone.haiku.ai (http and https)
reservoir.haiku.ai (http and https)
git.haiku.ai (http and https)

data.title: Software re-sell
data.description: Can I re-sell Animator? Do you have a re-sell process?
data.body: Unfortunately, no — currently we support only direct purchases.

data.title: 14-day free trial end
data.description: What happens with my projects once my 14-day trial is over?
data.body: You will still have access to your projects, source files, and previously generated code, but you will no longer be able to edit your projects or re-export them in any format after your trial expires.

data.title: Redeeming an Educational License coupon
data.description: Can I unlink my card after redeeming the coupon for 12 free months?
data.body: Our billing system requires a card to be linked while there's an active subscription, even when we're giving a 100% discount.  If you want to cancel your subscription at the end of the 12 months before being charged for the 13th, you should do so at that time (or of course you can cancel at any time before then, too).

data.title: Raster image support
data.description: Can I import and animate images in Animator?
data.body: At this moment you cannot import images, videos or GIFs into Animator. Only vector animation is supported.

data.title: Stroke and Stroke Width
data.description: Can I animate the stroke of an element inside Animator?
data.body: You can control the stroke on an element by adding the "Stroke width" property to it via the [+Add] button. You can control the color of the outline via Sketch or by adding the "Stroke" property.

data.title: Importing Lottie JSON files
data.description: Is it possible to import Lottie JSON files and then edit the animation?
data.body:
It is currently not possible.

It's theoretically possible, but it would be an incredible burden to maintain and make polished.  Lottie doesn't quite have a spec and often introduces breaking changes.  The Lottie format came from reverse-engineering the After Effects file format.

Our exporter is built by reverse-engineering Lottie's undocumented format and transpiling Animator Core's code format to Lottie's JSON.

So in short, we've filed this as a possible future feature — one which would unlock proper After Effects importing! — but it's not currently near the top of our backlog.

data.title: HaikuClock
data.description: How can I prevent HaikuClock from running by default?
data.body:
There is an API for not running the clock by default, as well as an API for turning it off after it starts here: https://github.com/HaikuTeam/core/blob/master/src/HaikuClock.ts#L26-L28

Check if the animation adapter is constructed somewhere in your code, even if it’s unused. You should be able to disable it with options like {clock: {run: false}}

data.title: Lottie markers
data.description: Does Animator support Lottie markers?
data.body:
Animator does not support Lottie markers.  I would recommend using either Progress Time or Frame Time instead.  You should be able to discern frame/time numbers from the timeline inside Animator.

https://www.npmjs.com/package/lottie-ios#play-with-progress-time

https://www.npmjs.com/package/lottie-ios#play-with-progress-time

data.title: Pause and then play the timeline
data.description: Is there a way to pause the timeline for a number of frames or ms and then play?
data.body:
You can do this with frame actions and a bit of JavaScript logic:

1- First, create a frame action by hovering on top of the frame in which you want to pause and clicking on the little + (plus) button that appears on top.
2- An editor will open, here you need to tell Animator to pause the animation, wait the desired time and play the animation again, you can express this in JavaScript with:

// pause the animation
this.getDefaultTimeline().pause();

// wait 1 second and play the animation again
setTimeout(() => {
  this.getDefaultTimeline().play();
}, 1000);

You can change 1000 to any arbitrary number of milliseconds.

3- In order to see if it works, click on the eye icon near the top-right corner of the app to enter Preview mode.


Here's a link to the project if you want to fork it and see how it works! https://share.haiku.ai/u/robertodip/pauseWaitAndPlayTwo

data.title: [Inspiration] Types of animations you can include in your product
data.description: How can I integrate a good animation into the UI?
data.body:
Common use-cases we've seen for self-contained animations are:

  1. Loading animations — keep users engaged and delighted to show that an app is "alive" rather than hanged during load-time.  Ex: Airbnb's loading spinner.

  2. Welcome tours — first-touch experience is so critical to user activation (in the product-marketing sense of the term), the more delight and polish you can pack into the NUX, the better.

  3. Doodles, polish, character — in the same way that illustrations-as-embellishment are in the design zeitgeist (see designbetter.co or gusto.com); self-contained animations are an excellent way to bring artistic character to your software, as a way to differentiate your brand & instill delight.

data.title: Contributing
data.description: Can I contribute to Animator Core?
data.body:
Animator Core is fully open source, it should be straight-forward for anyone to fork and make some nominal modifications to fit the needs of their team. We would welcome PRs back to the main project, too.

https://github.com/HaikuTeam/core

data.title: Footprint
data.description: Vendor bundle size alterations after introducing Haiku Core.
data.body:
The way the dependencies are copied into vendor in Core is unideal, but is a bit of legacy from the early days of the product.  Due to prioritization/limited resources, this is unlikely something that we'll get to refactoring soon (i.e. not within the next 3-6 months) — however, since Animator Core is fully open source, it should be straight-forward for anyone to fork and make some nominal modifications to make it a bit more sane & tree-shakable. We would welcome PRs back to the main project, too.

Another option for reducing footprint is to check out using lottie-web as your web runtime, as long as you don't need interactivity or framework adapters.

data.title: Credit card error
data.description: When I tried to purchase a license, my card was rejected. Why?
data.body:
Credit card processing is handled for us by a third party, Stripe.  Stripe fully determines whether to accept or reject payments, and unfortunately there's nothing we can do about overturning that.

All we can recommend is to try one more time with one of the cards you've already used and/or contacting your bank(s) to make sure there's nothing else blocking the transaction on that side.

data.title: Deleting properties from the timeline
data.description: Can I delete a property I added via the [+ Add] button?
data.body:
Once you've added a property to the timeline, you can't delete it in the current implementation. This feature is in our backlog though.

What you can do is delete the keyframes (including the one at frame 0) and tweens associated with that property, which will remove all effects from your animation.

data.title: Integrating into a React app
data.description: Would my animations work inside a React web app?
data.body:
Yes.  The default "Publish" has got you covered for React (also Angular, Vue, and vanilla HTML + JS,) and will support interactions + subcomponents.  

When you push Publish, just follow the instructions that pop up for "React."

More about Integrations here: https://help.haikuforteams.com/about-haiku/haiku-integrations

data.title: Accessing a State from an Action
data.description: Is it possible to access a state from a click function?
data.body:
Yes, from within an Action you can access any of your States via this.state.myStateName.

Make sure if you’re changing state you use this.setState({myStateName: 'newvaluehere'}) 


More resources:

  • https://www.haikuforteams.com/blog/understanding-states/

  • https://www.haikuforteams.com/blog/understanding-actions/

data.title: Animating the border radius
data.description: Is there a way to animate a border radius? For example, turn a circle into a rectangle.
data.body: To animate the border radius of an object, simply add the Rx and Ry properties via the [+ Add] button in the timeline.

data.title: Shortcuts
data.description: What are the available shortcuts in Animator?
data.body: Please check the full list here: https://docs.haikuforteams.com/using-haiku/keyboard-shortcuts-and-input.html

data.title: Reversing the timeline
data.description: Is there a way to reverse the timeline, for instance on a focus event?
data.body:
You can also control the timeline playhead using the Javascript API, either from the containing web codebase or inside an Action inside Animator — note that Lottie doesn't support this kind of interaction.

This API is documented here:  https://docs.haikuforteams.com/embedding-and-using-haiku/haiku-core-api.html  — you can search for .seek(

data.title: Standalone Json file
data.description: Is it possible to export a component as standalone .json file?
data.body:
If you want to use Lottie as your runtime, yes you can File > Export > Lottie and get a lottie.json.

If you want to keep interactions and a few other features that aren't supported by Lottie [1] — then the way Haiku Animator handles modularization is by using `npm` (or `yarn`).  This works best with Angular/React/Vue, and everything gets nicely bundled along with your existing codebase bundler.

If you're using vanilla HTML + JS, you need 1. the Animator Core runtime (https://www.github.com/HaikuTeam/core) and 2. the project file — these can't be boiled down to a single JSON file, because they both require code to be executed to run.

[1] https://docs.haikuforteams.com/embedding-and-using-haiku/lottie.html
